| notable role = }} '''Jerry McCord Van Dyke''' (July 27, 1931 – January 5, 2018) was an American actor, musician and comedian. He was the younger brother of [[Dick Van Dyke]].{{cite web|title=Jerry Van Dyke|url=https://www.nytimes.com/movies/person/72853/Jerry-Van-Dyke/biography|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=January 6, 2018}} Van Dyke made his television acting debut on ''[[The Dick Van Dyke Show]]'' with several guest appearances as Rob Petrie's brother Stacey. While his infrequent starring roles were typically in poorly received sitcoms (''[[My Mother the Car]]'', one of the shows where he was the lead actor, is considered one of the [[List of sitcoms notable for negative reception|worst sitcoms of all time]]), he enjoyed a long and successful career as a [[character actor]] in supporting and guest roles. From 1989 to 1997 he portrayed Luther Van Dam in ''[[Coach (TV series)|Coach]]''. ==Early life== Van Dyke was born in [[Danville, Illinois]] on July 27, 1931, to Hazel Victoria ([[Maiden and married names|née]] McCord; 1896–1992), a stenographer, and Loren Wayne "Cookie" Van Dyke (1898–1976), a salesman.{{cite web|url=http://www.foxnews.com/entertainment/2018/01/06/jerry-van-dyke-comedian-and-actor-dead-at-age-86.html|title=Jerry Van Dyke, comedian and actor, dead at age 86|publisher=[[Fox News Channel]]|date=January 6, 2018|access-date=January 6, 2018}} He was of [[Dutch people|Dutch]], [[English people|English]], and [[Scottish people|Scottish]] descent. His mother was a ''[[Mayflower]]'' descendant.{{cite web|url=http://www.officialdickvandyke.com/biography/|title=Biography – The Official Site of Dick Van Dyke|website=Officialdickvandyke.com|access-date=January 6, 2018}} ==Career== ===Early career=== [[File:Stefanie Powers-Jerry Van Dyke in McLintock!.jpg|thumb|left|Van Dyke with [[Stefanie Powers]] in ''McLintock!'' (1963)]] Van Dyke pursued his [[stand-up comedy]] career while still in [[Danville High School (Illinois)|Danville High School]] and was already a veteran of strip joints and nightclubs when he joined the [[United States Air Force]] [[Tops In Blue]] in 1954 and 1955.Tops in Blue Our Story Published by Air Force Entertainment, 2005{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/06/obituaries/jerry-van-dyke-dead.html|title=Jerry Van Dyke, 'Coach' Actor and Foil for His Brother, Dick, Dies at 86|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=January 6, 2018|access-date=January 6, 2018}} During the mid-1950s, Van Dyke worked at [[WTHI-TV]] in [[Terre Haute, Indiana]].{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/tv/news/jerry-van-dyke-coach-actor-and-comedian-dead-at-86-w515090|title=Jerry Van Dyke, 'Coach' Actor and Comedian, Dies at 86|work=[[Rolling Stone]]|date=January 6, 2018|access-date=January 6, 2018}} ''The Jerry Van Dyke Show'', which included future [[CBS]] News ''Early Show'' news anchor Joseph Benti, Nancee South and Ben Falber, was popular fare. In the service, he performed at military bases around the world, twice winning the ''All Air Force Talent Show''. Following his first guest appearances on ''The Dick Van Dyke Show'' and two others on CBS's ''[[The Ed Sullivan Show]]'', CBS made him a regular on ''[[The Judy Garland Show]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/movies/la-et-st-jerry-van-dyke-obituary-20180106-story.html|title=Jerry Van Dyke, comic actor known for TV's 'Coach,' dies at 86|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=January 6, 2018|access-date=January 6, 2018}} He was also given hosting chores on the 1963 game show ''Picture This''. In that same year, movie audiences saw him in supporting roles in ''[[McLintock!]]'', ''[[Palm Springs Weekend]]'' and ''[[The Courtship of Eddie's Father (film)|The Courtship of Eddie's Father]]''. ===Television career=== [[File:Jerry Van Dyke Accidental Family (cropped).JPG|thumb|right|Van Dyke in a publicity photo for ''[[Accidental Family]]'' (1967)]] In 1963 Van Dyke was cast on an episode of ''[[GE True]]'', hosted by [[Jack Webb]].{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2018/tv/news/jerry-van-dyke-coach-actor-dead-dies-1202655598/|title=Jerry Van Dyke, Emmy-Nominated 'Coach' Actor, Dies at 86|work=Variety|date=January 6, 2018|access-date=January 6, 2018}} When ''The Judy Garland Show'' was unsuccessfully revamped, Van Dyke left the program. He turned down the offer to play [[Gilligan (Gilligan's Island)|Gilligan]] on ''[[Gilligan's Island]]'', a role which instead went to [[Bob Denver]]. He rejected as well an offer to replace [[Don Knotts]] as Sheriff Andy Taylor's deputy on ''[[The Andy Griffith Show]]''. Van Dyke finally accepted the lead role of attorney David Crabtree in ''[[My Mother the Car]]'' (1965), the misadventures of a man whose deceased mother Gladys (voiced by [[Ann Sothern]]) is reincarnated as a restored antique car. Though the series was a commercial failure, Van Dyke continued to work steadily in supporting television and film roles through the rest of the decade. He starred in another short-lived situation comedy ''[[Accidental Family]]'' (1967) as widowed comedian Jerry Webster who buys a farm to raise his son while he is not away on professional tours. He was also featured in ''[[Love and Kisses (film)|Love and Kisses]]'' (1965) and as [[Andy Griffith]]'s co-star in ''[[Angel in My Pocket]]'' (1969). During the 1970s Van Dyke returned to stand-up comedy. He spent much of the decade touring [[Playboy Club]]s around the country and headlining venues in [[Las Vegas]] and [[Reno, Nevada]], [[Summerfest]] in [[Milwaukee]], and in [[Atlantic City, New Jersey]]. He returned to television for guest appearances on ''[[Love, American Style]]'' and ''[[Fantasy Island]]''. In 1973 he portrayed Wes Callison, News Writer, on the season four episode "Son of 'But Seriously, Folks'" on ''[[The Mary Tyler Moore Show]]''.{{cite web|url=http://ew.com/tv/2018/01/06/jerry-van-dyke-dead-dick-van-dyke-brother/|title=Jerry Van Dyke, Coach Star and Dick Van Dyke's Brother, Dies at 86|work=Entertainment Weekly|date=January 6, 2018|access-date=January 6, 2018}} He also had roles in ''[[ABC Afterschool Special#Season Four .281975.E2.80.9376.29|The Amazing Cosmic Awareness of Duffy Moon]]'' (1976) and ''[[13 Queens Boulevard]]'' (1979).Also in 1989 he appeared as a panelist in the pilot for the revival of ''[[Match Game]]'', hosted by [[Bert Convy]], but due to his brain tumor, he was later replaced by [[Ross Shafer]] when it was turned into a series in 1990. In 1988 he made a guest appearance on [[Scott Baio]]'s sitcom ''[[Charles in Charge]]'' as Jamie Powell's health teacher Mr. Merkin. In 1989 Van Dyke began portraying beloved, yet befuddled, assistant coach Luther Van Dam on the long-running series ''[[Coach (TV series)|Coach]]''. For this role, he received four consecutive [[Emmy Award]] nominations (1990 through 1993) for "Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Comedy Series". ===Later career=== In 1995 he appeared in a series of [[Hardee's]] commercials to promote the [[Big Hardee]], then in the late 1990s acted as the spokesperson for [[Big Lots]]. He appeared in ''[[Yes, Dear]]'' as Big Jimmy, the father of Jimmy Hughes. He made a guest appearance on a [[List of My Name Is Earl episodes#Season 4: 2008–09|September 2008 episode]] of ''[[My Name Is Earl]]'' and in 2010 he made an appearance on the second-season episode, "A Simple Christmas" of the television series, ''[[The Middle (TV series)|The Middle]]'', playing Frankie's father, Tag Spence. He returned in "Thanksgiving III" in November 2011, "Thanksgiving IV" in November 2012, "From Orson with Love" in May 2013, "Thanksgiving V" in November 2013. and “Flirting with disaster” in March 2015. Van Dyke also played the object of Maw Maw's affections on the 18th episode of the first season of ''[[Raising Hope]]''. In a December 2013 episode of ''[[The Millers]]'' he played Bud Miller, father to [[Margo Martindale]]'s character, Carol. In his final television role in April 2015 he reprised his role as Frankie's father on ''[[The Middle (TV series)|The Middle]]'', along with real-life brother [[Dick Van Dyke]] playing his character's brother.{{cite web|url=http://abc.go.com/shows/the-middle/episode-guide/season-06/22-two-of-a-kind|title=The Middle: Two of a Kind Recap – Season 6 Episode 21|publisher=ABC}}{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/tv/la-et-st-van-dyke-brothers-the-middle-20150422-story.html|title=Brothers Dick and Jerry Van Dyke clash in 'The Middle,' bond off-screen|date=April 22, 2015|work=Los Angeles Times}} ==Personal life== Van Dyke was married twice and had three children with first wife Carol, daughters Jerri Lynn and Kelly Jean and son Ronald. [[Kelly Jean Van Dyke]] committed suicide in 1991, following struggles with substance abuse.{{cite web|title=The Death of Twins Peak actor Jack Nance was as strange as the characters he played.|url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20143430,00.html|work=[[People (magazine)|People]]|access-date=March 13, 2014|author=Kyle Smith|author2=Lorenzo Benet|date=February 10, 1997}} Jerry and wife Shirley resided together on their 800-acre ranch near [[Hot Springs, Arkansas]]. Van Dyke was an avid poker player and announced a number of poker tournaments for [[ESPN]] in the late 1990s and early 2000s. He was also a four-string [[banjo]] player with several performances on ''The Dick Van Dyke Show'' to his credit. ==Death== On January 5, 2018, Van Dyke died at his Arkansas ranch, of heart failure at the age of 86. He was in declining health since being involved in a car accident two years earlier.{{cite web |url=http://www.tmz.com/2018/01/06/jerry-van-dyke-dead-at-86/ |title=Jerry Van Dyke Dead at 86 |magazine=TMZ |date=January 6, 2018 |access-date=January 6, 2018}} {{portal|Biography|Illinois|California|Arkansas|Film|Television|Comedy|Music}} ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== {{commons category|Jerry Van Dyke}} * {{IMDb name|0886733}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Van Dyke, Jerry}} [[Category:1931 births]] [[Category:2018 deaths]] [[Category:American male film actors]] [[Category:American male television actors]] [[Category:American banjoists]] [[Category:Poker commentators]] [[Category:American people of Dutch descent]] [[Category:American people of English descent]] [[Category:American people of Irish descent]] [[Category:American people of Scottish descent]] [[Category:United States Air Force airmen]] [[Category:Male actors from Illinois]] [[Category:Male actors from Arkansas]] [[Category:People from Danville, Illinois]] [[Category:People from Malvern, Arkansas]] [[Category:Military personnel from Illinois]] [[Category:Van Dyke family|Jerry]] [[Category:20th-century American male actors]] [[Category:21st-century American male actors]]
